posts.post_content:
Are you mad Volcre? I've see Boggy Hellkite used, and brutal isn't the word. And the more draconic the deck, the more brutal it is. Hell, I'd go so far as to say that its the best dragon to see play.
  
   
5/5 flash flying with a blaster effect... seriously, this is up there with kokosho the Evening Star on the brutality scale. Flash it in, kill a godsire and 2 damage to their face, revive it, 5 damage to the face again (bladewing the risen anyone?) then it swings for 5 power. Seriously, you wanna question a card's rarity, question Vampire Nocturnus, Conflux, or Aven Mimomancer first.
  
   
God I want a playset of these.

posts.post_content: great flash, great stats, great flying, great comes into play ability, there must be a drawback? Oh yeah, 8 mana.......... if you are playing dragons, you are in red, if you like the burn effect, you are probably playing red as well. If you are playing red and need an 8-drop to win the game, you may as well concede. There is a kind of spell you use when you need a topdeck win late game for red, it's called an X spell, I happen to know a REALLY good one called BANEFIRE. lets see, 8 mana for a 5/5 that will egt removed right away, probably even countered, and might do 5 damage? or 8 mana for 7 damage that can't be countered, and can't be prevented. you decide.

OUTLANDISH. DON'T READ UNLESS YOU'RE INTO WACKY COMBO DECKS.

1 Wheel of Fortune  
  
Creatures:

took awhile to get it together, but I think that, as insane as it is, it'd be fun to whack people with this one. While mainly built to blow up a player in one hit, it does give you four 5/5 dragons to play with for multiplayer mayhem. fun fun. Should be interesting to see what happens.

Posted By: ElbowWarrior (12/4/2009 4:26:23 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: @Ficitonarius: I'd imagine not. You might want to check with someone with more experience in complicated rules, but from the sound of it, it's a case of "even if the original source is gone (that is, the hellkite in this case) the ability still resolves once it's on the stack". So even though you're now the controller, the ability went on the stack with the original controller having the choice as to how the damage is divided, and I can't imagine that would change as they put that ability on the stack.
posts.html:
@Ficitonarius: I'd imagine not. You might want to check with someone with more experience in complicated rules, but from the sound of it, it's a case of "even if the original source is gone (that is, the hellkite in this case) the ability still resolves once it's on the stack". So even though you're now the controller, the ability went on the stack with the original controller having the choice as to how the damage is divided, and I can't imagine that would change as they put that ability on the stack.

posts.post_content:
Question: I have a [Dominating Licid](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dominating Licid) in play untapped and ready to uh, Dominate.  
My opponent slaps down a [Bogarden Hellkite](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bogarden Hellkite). It resolves and "enters the battlefield".  
However, it's triggered ability uses the stack, so I respond by putting my Dominating Licid's activated ability on top of it. My Dominating Licid's ability resolves first, giving me control of the Hellkite. Then it's triggered ability resolves. Wouldn't it resolve in reference to me, allowing me to \*\*\*ign the damage, since I'm now it's controller?
